body_text.text: The COVID-19 global pandemic has brought a time of grave uncertainty for U.S. healthcare and the greater economy. While the focus of healthcare providers is, appropriately, on the access to and delivery of care to those impacted by the COVID-19 outbreak, there are many independent specialists who will require financial resources to persevere during a time when they are unable to conduct regular business.

A recent survey of 724 physician respondents in the first week of April 2020 reported that 97% of medical practices have been negatively impacted directly or indirectly by COVID-19.1 A 70% decrease in surgical procedures and a 33% decrease in office visit was reported. Importantly, 75% of respondents were in independent practices consisting of fewer than 50 full-time equivalent physicians. The 2017 Society for Vascular Surgery workforce survey, consisting of 714 respondents, found that 44.6% were in academic practice, 23.6% in self-employed private practice, 19.9% in hospital employed private practice, and 12% in a group private practice.2 In the context of this discussion, ‘independent’ Vascular Surgeons are those in self-employed private practice, group private practice as well in some instances hospital employed private practice depending on how the employment agreement is structured. Although all Vascular Surgeons benefit from recent legislation passed by the U.S. Congress, fund disbursement will be different for academic, employed Vascular Surgeons compared to solo practitioners or those working in legal entities where each Vascular Surgeons has their own Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN). This article will discuss the various resources currently available to Vascular Surgeons.

On March 27, 2020, President Trump signed a $2 trillion economic stabilization package, the Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act, that among other things, provides direct funding to the healthcare industry (including physicians and physician practices) through a number of measures. Most significantly, the Act provides $100 billion to the Department of Health & Human Services (HHS) Public Health and Social Services Emergency Fund, to be used “for necessary expenses to reimburse, through grants or other mechanisms, eligible health care providers for health care related expenses or lost revenues that are attributable to coronavirus.”3 Of this total, $30 billion is currently being disbursed directly to providers (payments began April 10th) for the purpose of reimbursing expenses and lost revenue related to COVID-19; these funds, which are based on the provider’s share of their 2019 Medicare fee-for-service (FFS) reimbursement,4 do not have to be repaid.5 Note that, these advances (much like the programs other discussed below) will be remitted to the organization whose TIN bills Medicare; consequently, individual physicians would not directly receive these payments.3 As to the remaining $70 billion, the federal government is working to provide targeted provider disbursements to those providers most affected by the pandemic, such as rural providers and providers who provide care to large numbers of Medicaid and uninsured patients.3 Of note, physicians and others employed or their companies owned/ operated by private equity firms will not be eligible for the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP).

In addition to direct healthcare provider payments, the CARES Act implemented a number of temporary Small Business Administration (SBA) loan programs for small businesses (including physician practices) (Table I
):(1)The Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), to which $349 billion was allocated;(2)The Emergency Economic Injury Disaster Loans (EIDL);(3)The Coronavirus Economic Stabilization Act (CESA); and,(4)The Small Business Debt Relief Program.6

HHS has also taken agency action, separate from Congress, to distribute almost $34 billion to providers through the much-expanded Accelerated and Advance Payment Program.7 Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, this program had approved only 100 requests for accelerated/advance payment over the past five years.7 Since approximately April 1st, CMS has approved over 17,000 such requests, with payments being issued within seven days.7

A couple of noteworthy points regarding these programs:(1)Businesses may obtain loans under both the PPP and the EIDL, so long as they cover different expenses;6 and,(2)Providers who receive more than $150,000 in total federal government funding related to COVID-19 will be required to submit a report to HHS disclosing the total amount received and an itemized list of how the received funds were spent. 8

Although not immediate, physician practices may also be eligible for various tax credits. For example, the Employee Retention Tax Credit provides an employee retention tax credit of 50% on wages, up to $10,000 per employee. This credit is applicable to wages paid or incurred between March 13 and December 31, 2020, as well as a portion of the cost of employer-provided healthcare benefits.9 Eligible businesses include those who are not in receipt of a PPP loan and whose: (1) operations have been fully/partly suspended due to a Stay at Home Order; or (2) gross receipts declined by more than 50% compared to same quarter of 2019.

In addition, there are many laws which impact Vascular Surgeons that have been relaxed, and new rules that have been written, for this national emergency. These include:(1)A 20% increase in Medicare payments to hospitals related to treatment of COVID-19 inpatients;3
(2)A suspension of Medicare sequestration (which will effectively increase most Medicare provider reimbursement by 2%) through the end of 2020;(3)An expansion of the scope of practice for non-physician providers and medical residents;(4)An expansion of reimbursable telehealth services, allowing Medicare providers, including Vascular Surgeons, to provide more than 80 additional services to beneficiaries, regardless of whether the beneficiary is in a rural community, or whether the provider is located out of state. These services are currently allowed to be provided via non-secure apps, such as Skype and Facetime;10
(5)An expansion of state Good Samaritan laws to protect from liability physicians providing volunteer medical services relating to the diagnosis, prevention, or treatment of suspected or actual COVID-19;3
(6)A relaxation of certain drug approval requirements – for example, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) must expedite drug application and inspection reviews to avert or alleviate a drug shortage;3
(7)Ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) can enroll and bill as a hospital, or alternatively, contract with hospitals to provide hospital services;11
(8)Physician-owned hospitals may increase their number of beds;11 and,(9)Hospitals may provide benefits and support to medical staff, e.g., child care services, laundry service, multiple daily meals.

According to the Medical Group Management Association, independent physician practices have already experienced an average decline in patient volume of 60% and revenues of 55% since the beginning of this public health crisis.12 Further, 48% of surveyed practices have been forced to enact temporary furloughs and 22% have permanently laid off staff. 12 Should healthcare providers, and particularly physicians, not receive additional funding, the COVID-19 pandemic could decimate the U.S. independent physician workforce. For example, a HealthLandscape and American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP) study estimates that approximately 60,000 family practices will close or significantly scale back, laying off 800,000 employees, if things remain the same.13

The next steps to deal with the financial challenge for Vascular Surgeons depend on how long mitigation steps continue nationwide. While it is impossible to predict what the long-term consequences for small and medium size VS practices will be, insolvency is a possibility pushing surgeons to seek safety and employment with larger groups or health systems. Meanwhile, the short-term financial implications are worrisome. On April 16, 2020 the SBA announced that the $349 billion program to assist small business ran out of funds.14 Already, 1.1 million applications asking for $257 billion had been approved by the SBA.15 What is not clear at this time is how much of that amount has been claimed by physicians.

In the coming weeks, Vascular Surgeons can expect the federal government to distribute the remaining $70 billion in the Relief Fund to providers, although how that amount will be allocated is yet indeterminate. Further, it is possible that Congress will pass a fourth stimulus plan, although movement forward on that bill is being held up by political posturing.16 Hospital associations are advocating for an additional $100 billion in grants to hospitals, while community health centers are seeking $7.6 billion in emergency funds.17 Rural health providers, while not requesting a specific amount of money, are asking for 20% of any addition funds to be allocated directly to rural providers (reasoning that they serve 20% of the U.S. population).17 On the individual physician level, a number of professional physician associations, including the American Medical Association, are imploring HHS Secretary Alex Azar to financial relief to physicians in the form of one month worth of revenue to every Medicare-enrolled physician and advanced practice clinician.18 Similarly, the AAFP is lobbying Congress to provide hazard pay for primary care physicians in the amount of $200 per attributed Medicare beneficiary.19 The results of any such advocacy, however, remains to be seen. From a surgeon’s perspective, much better coordination between the American College of Surgeons and all surgical specialty organizations including our Society need to be at the forefront to assist our members in accessing and applying for these and any other resources to help practices, especially those not associated with employment at major health systems.
